climbs.name: Where Did All This Feces Come From?

content.description: Start on the most incut part of the massive rail, move up and left to a crimp, then make a big move up to a jug that you need to go super far into to get the good part. Continue directly up on crimps and shelves to an easy topout.
content.location:
It is about four feet right of

I Need A Heeler

.

Start on the big rail on a jug.

content.description:
Sit start on two half-pad-ish crimps beneath and to the right of the bulge that acts as the top out for

Pads are for Losers

. Move straight up then just a little over the bulge out left, utilizing the juggy rail on the upper right corner of the bulge, directly above the deep sort-of triangular cavity. I had to do an awkward mantel thing to top this out, but I'm sure better beta is out there. If this is already a problem that's been given a name and you know about it, shoot me a PM!
content.protection: A pad for the top out is nice but not necessary.

content.description: Start on a big ledge (yellow circle), bump up, reach over to a crimp or a jug, and traverse over to to another jug. Get a high foot, and top out.
content.location:
Start a little to to the left of

Pads Are For Losers

.

content.description:
Start with a right-hand sloper, a left-hand slopey pinch, and great left heel hook. Traverse [right] with heel hooks two jugs at the left end. Keep traversing [right] almost to the tree, and top out the bulge on small holds with high feet.

Note: the edit on going right instead of left was suggested by

Craig Waller

.
content.protection: It is mostly close to the ground, so pads are not really necessary.
content.location:
This is just left of

Lowered Expectations

.

A dark water line separates the two start holds.

content.description:
Don't let the name fool you. Lowered Expectations is named for its proximity to the ground, not your experience! (However, the FA beta did end up being a little easier than I first estimated.)

Sit start with your butt in the dirt on two small crimps, the left with a nice thumb catch, and make a big move to a sloping rail. From here, keep body tension to execute a big dyno to a jug.
content.location: This is on the East face of the boulder.

content.description: Start matched on a well defined crimp rail, and do a move up right to a sloper-jug. Set a kneebar by moving your right foot up, and go up left to a good sidepull. Maintain body tension to move your right hand to a sloper, and cruise up the top section to an easy mantel.
content.location: This is the furthest line to the right on the overhanging section. The starting hold is well defined, you can't miss it.

content.description:
Start almost laying on the ground on a jug rail, pop in a heel hook, and make a big move out right to a slopey crimp. From that crimp, fire into another full pad, incut crimp. Make a few moves on slopey shelves to a blank topout.

This will be tough for anyone over 5'9".
content.location:
It is on the face nearest to the trail that stays high.

The nature trail the boulder is on has numbered posts, this problem is directly in line with the #12 post. There is some bright lime green lichen that is near the start hold.

content.description:
Hellacious Heel Hooks is a little harder than

Lowered Expectations

with a really hard first move. Start on the obvious sloppy rail, make a big move to another sloper, bump up a little higher to a better hold, and continue the easy mantel. This is a very height-dependent climb. Let me know if this already has a name or who had the FA.
content.location:
It is just to the right of

Lowered Expectations

on the east side of the boulder.

content.description: Start on a good ledge (circled in blue in the picture), make a big move to another jug, then go to a crimp, make a high foot, and continue the easy topout.
content.location:
It is just to the left of

Traverses Are For Losers

.
